ENE-4.C.4
In some cases, it is necessary to consider both
enthalpy and entropy to determine if a process
will be thermodynamically favored. The freezing
of water and the dissolution of sodium nitrate
are examples of such phenomena.
ENE-4.C.5
Knowing the values of ΔHo
 and ΔSo
 for a
process at a given temperature allows ΔGo to
be calculated directly.
EQN: ΔG° = ΔH° - T ΔS°
ENE-4.C.6
In general, the temperature conditions for a
process to be thermodynamically favored
(ΔGo < 0) can be predicted from the signs of

TOPIC 9.4
Thermodynamic and
Kinetic Control
Required Course Content
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
ENE-4
Some chemical or physical processes cannot occur without intervention.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
ENE-4.D
Explain, in terms of kinetics,
why a thermodynamically
favored reaction might not
occur at a measurable rate.
ENE-4.D.1
Many processes that are thermodynamically
favored do not occur to any measurable extent,
or they occur at extremely slow rates.
ENE-4.D.2
Processes that are thermodynamically favored,
but do not proceed at a measurable rate, are
under “kinetic control.” High activation energy
is a common reason for a process to be under
kinetic control. The fact that a process does
not proceed at a noticeable rate does not mean
that the chemical system is at equilibrium. If
a process is known to be thermodynamically
favored, and yet does not occur at a
measurable rate, it is reasonable to conclude
that the process is under kinetic control.
TOPIC 9.5
Free Energy and
Equilibrium
Required Course Content
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
ENE-5
The relationship between ΔG° and K can be used to determine favorability of a
chemical or physical transformation.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
ENE-5.A
Explain whether a process is
thermodynamically favored
using the relationships
between K, ΔGo
, and T.
ENE-5.A.1
The phrase “thermodynamically favored”
(ΔGo < 0) means that the products are favored
at equilibrium (K > 1).
ENE-5.A.2
The equilibrium constant is related to free
energy by the equations
EQN: K = e-ΔG°/RT
and
EQN: ΔG° = -RT ln K.
ENE-5.A.3
Connections between K and ΔG° can be made
qualitatively through estimation. When ΔG° is
near zero, the equilibrium constant will be close
to 1. When ΔG° is much larger or much smaller
than RT, the value of K deviates strongly from 1.
ENE-5.A.4
Processes with ΔG° < 0 favor products
(i.e., K > 1) and those with ΔG° > 0 favor
reactants (i.e., K < 1).
TOPIC 9.6
Coupled Reactions
Required Course Content
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
ENE-5
The relationship between ΔG° and K can be used to determine favorability of a
chemical or physical transformation.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
ENE-5.B
Explain the relationship
between external sources
of energy or coupled
reactions and their ability
to drive thermodynamically
unfavorable processes.
ENE-5.B.1
An external source of energy can be used
to make a thermodynamically unfavorable
process occur. Examples include:
a. Electrical energy to drive an electrolytic cell
or charge a battery.
b. Light to drive the overall conversion of carbon
dioxide to glucose in photosynthesis.
ENE-5.B.2
A desired product can be formed by coupling
a thermodynamically unfavorable reaction
that produces that product to a favorable
reaction (e.g., the conversion of ATP to
ADP in biological systems). In the coupled
system, the individual reactions share one
or more common intermediates. The sum of
the individual reactions produces an overall
reaction that achieves the desired outcome and
has ΔG° < 0.

Galvanic (Voltaic) and

LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
ENE-6.A
Explain the relationship
between the physical
components of an
electrochemical cell and the
overall operational principles
of the cell.
ENE-6.A.1
Each component of an electrochemical cell
(electrodes, solutions in the half-cells, salt
bridge, voltage/current measuring device) plays
a specific role in the overall functioning of the
cell. The operational characteristics of the cell
(galvanic vs. electrolytic, direction of electron flow,
reactions occurring in each half-cell, change in
electrode mass, evolution of a gas at an electrode,
ion flow through the salt bridge) can be described
at both the macroscopic and particulate levels.
ENE-6.A.2
Galvanic, sometimes called voltaic, cells involve
a thermodynamically favored reaction, whereas
electrolytic cells involve a thermodynamically
unfavored reaction. Visual representations
of galvanic and electrolytic cells are tools of
analysis to identify where half-reactions occur
and in what direction current flows.
ENE-6.A.3
For all electrochemical cells, oxidation
occurs at the anode and reduction occurs
at the cathode.
X LABELING AN ELECTRODE AS POSITIVE OR
Rationale: Sign conventions vary depending
on the type of electrochemical cell, even though
oxidation always occurs at the anode.

ENE-6.B.1
Electrochemistry encompasses the
study of redox reactions that occur within
electrochemical cells. The reactions are
either thermodynamically favored (resulting
in a positive voltage) or thermodynamically
unfavored (resulting in a negative voltage and
requiring an externally applied potential for the

The standard cell potential of electrochemical

respective standard reduction potentials.

TOPIC 9.9
Cell Potential Under
Nonstandard Conditions
Required Course Content
ENDURING UNDERSTANDING
ENE-6
Electrical energy can be generated by chemical reactions.
LEARNING OBJECTIVE ESSENTIAL KNOWLEDGE
ENE-6.C
Explain the relationship
between deviations from
standard cell conditions and
changes in the cell potential.
ENE-6.C.1
In a real system under nonstandard conditions,
the cell potential will vary depending on the
concentrations of the active species. The cell
potential is a driving force toward equilibrium;
the farther the reaction is from equilibrium, the
greater the magnitude of the cell potential.
ENE-6.C.2
Equilibrium arguments such as Le Châtelier’s
principle do not apply to electrochemical
systems, because the systems are not in
equilibrium.
ENE-6.C.3
The standard cell potential Eo
 corresponds to
the standard conditions of Q = 1. As the system
approaches equilibrium, the magnitude (i.e.,
absolute value) of the cell potential decreases,
reaching zero at equilibrium (when Q = K).
Deviations from standard conditions that take
the cell further from equilibrium than Q = 1 will
increase the magnitude of the cell potential
relative to Eo
. Deviations from standard
conditions that take the cell closer to equilibrium
than Q = 1 will decrease the magnitude of the
cell potential relative to Eo
. In concentration
cells, the direction of spontaneous electron flow
can be determined by considering the direction
needed to reach equilibrium. 
ENE-6.C.4
Algorithmic calculations using the Nernst
equation are insufficient to demonstrate an
understanding of electrochemical cells under
nonstandard conditions. However, students
should qualitatively understand the effects
of concentration on cell potential and use
conceptual reasoning, including the qualitative
use of the Nernst equation:
EQN: E = Eo - (RT/nF) ln Q
to solve problems.

response:
Here are the key takeaways from the provided content:

**Topic 1.1: Moles and Molar Mass**

* The mole concept allows different units to be compared.
* Essential knowledge includes calculating quantities of a substance or its relative number of particles using dimensional analysis and the mole concept.
* Key concepts include Avogadro's number, molar mass, and the connection between mass and number of particles.

**Topic 1.2: Mass Spectroscopy of Elements**

* Mass spectroscopy can be used to determine the identity of an element's isotopes and their relative abundance.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the quantitative relationship between the mass spectrum of an element and its isotopes.
* Key concepts include mass-to-charge ratio, isotopic mass, and relative abundance.

**Topic 1.3: Elemental Composition of Pure Substances**

* Chemical formulas identify substances by their unique combination of atoms.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the quantitative relationship between the elemental composition by mass and the empirical formula of a pure substance.
* Key concepts include empirical formula, law of definite proportions, and atomic mass units (amu).

**Topic 1.4: Composition of Mixtures**

* Mixtures contain molecules or formula units of two or more types, whose relative proportions can vary.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the quantitative relationship between the elemental composition by mass and the composition of substances in a mixture.
* Key concepts include mixture composition, relative proportions, and atomic mass units (amu).

**Topic 1.5: Atomic Structure and Electron Configuration**

* Atoms and molecules can be identified by their electron distribution and energy.
* Essential knowledge includes representing the electron configuration of an element or ions of an element using the Aufbau principle.
* Key concepts include electron configuration, Aufbau principle, and atomic structure.

**Topic 1.6: Photoelectron Spectroscopy**

* Photoelectron spectroscopy (PES) can be used to measure the energies of electrons in a given shell.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between the photoelectron spectrum of an atom or ion and its electron configuration.
* Key concepts include PES, electron configuration, and energy levels.

**Topic 1.7: Periodic Trends**

* The periodic table shows patterns in electronic structure and trends in atomic properties.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between trends in atomic properties of elements and electronic structure and periodicity.
* Key concepts include periodic table, electronic structure, and atomic properties.

**Topic 1.8: Valence Electrons and Ionic Compounds**

* The likelihood that two elements will form a chemical bond is determined by the interactions between their valence electrons and nuclei.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between trends in the reactivity of elements and periodicity.
* Key concepts include valence electrons, periodic table, and chemical bonding.

**Topic 1.9: Types of Chemical Bonds**

* Electronegativity values for representative elements increase going from left to right across a period and decrease going down a group.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between the type of bonding and the properties of the elements participating in the bond.
* Key concepts include electronegativity, chemical bonding, and covalent bonds.

**Topic 1.10: Intramolecular Force and Potential Energy**

* A graph of potential energy versus distance between atoms is a useful representation for describing the interactions between atoms.
* Essential knowledge includes representing the relationship between potential energy and distance between atoms.
* Key concepts include potential energy, intramolecular forces, and bond energy.

**Topic 1.11: Structure of Ionic Solids**

* The cations and anions in an ionic crystal are arranged in a systematic, periodic 3-D array that maximizes the attractive forces among cations and anions while minimizing the repulsive forces.
* Essential knowledge includes representing an ionic solid with a particulate model that is consistent with Coulomb's law and the properties of the constituent ions.
* Key concepts include ionic crystal, Coulomb's law, and particulate model.

**Topic 1.12: Structure of Metals and Alloys**

* Metallic bonding can be represented as an array of positive metal ions surrounded by delocalized valence electrons.
* Essential knowledge includes representing a metallic solid and/or alloy using a model to show essential characteristics of the structure and interactions present in the substance.
* Key concepts include metallic bonding, delocalized electrons, and metal alloys.

**Topic 1.13: Lewis Diagrams**

* Lewis diagrams can be constructed according to an established set of principles.
* Essential knowledge includes representing a molecule with a Lewis diagram.
* Key concepts include Lewis diagram, valence shell electron pair repulsion (VSEPR), and molecular structure.

**Topic 1.14: Resonance and Formal Charge**

* In cases where more than one equivalent Lewis structure can be constructed, resonance must be included as a refinement to the Lewis structure.
* Essential knowledge includes representing a molecule with a Lewis diagram that accounts for resonance between equivalent structures or that uses formal charge to select between nonequivalent structures.
* Key concepts include resonance, formal charge, and Lewis structure.

**Topic 1.15: VSEPR and Bond Hybridization**

* VSEPR theory uses the Coulombic repulsion between electrons as a basis for predicting the arrangement of electron pairs around a central atom.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining structural properties of molecules based on Lewis diagrams, VSEPR theory, bond orders, and bond polarities.
* Key concepts include VSEPR, Lewis diagram, bond order, and bond polarity.

**Topic 1.16: Intermolecular Forces**

* London dispersion forces are a result of the Coulombic interactions between temporary, fluctuating dipoles.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between the chemical structures of molecules and the relative strength of their intermolecular forces.
* Key concepts include intermolecular forces, London dispersion forces, and molecular structure.

**Topic 1.17: Properties of Solids**

* Many properties of liquids and solids are determined by the strengths and types of intermolecular forces present.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship among the macroscopic properties of a substance, the particulate-level structure of the substance, and the interactions between these particles.
* Key concepts include intermolecular forces, particulate-level structure, and macroscopic properties.

**Topic 1.18: Solids, Liquids, and Gases**

* Matter exists in three states: solid, liquid, and gas, and their differences are influenced by variances in spacing and motion of the molecules.
* Essential knowledge includes representing the differences between solid, liquid, and gas phases using a particulate-level model.
* Key concepts include particulate-level model, solid, liquid, and gas phases.

**Topic 1.19: Ideal Gas Law**

* The macroscopic properties of ideal gases are related through the ideal gas law.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between the macroscopic properties of a sample of gas or mixture of gases using the ideal gas law.
* Key concepts include ideal gas law, PV=nRT, and partial pressure.

**Topic 1.20: Kinetic Molecular Theory**

* The kinetic molecular theory (KMT) relates the macroscopic properties of gases to motions of the particles in the gas.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between the motion of particles and the macroscopic properties of gases with the KMT.
* Key concepts include KMT, Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution, and kinetic energy.

**Topic 1.21: Deviation from Ideal Gas Law**

* The ideal gas law does not explain the actual behavior of real gases.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship among non-ideal behaviors of gases, interparticle forces, and/or volumes.
* Key concepts include interparticle forces, non-ideal behavior, and real gases.

**Topic 1.22: Solutions and Mixtures**

* Solutions can be solids, liquids, or gases.
* Essential knowledge includes calculating the number of solute particles, volume, or molarity of solutions.
* Key concepts include solution composition, molarity, and particulate model.

**Topic 1.23: Representations of Solutions**

* Particulate representations of solutions can be used to communicate the structure and properties of solutions.
* Essential knowledge includes representing interactions between components and concentrations of components using particulate models.
* Key concepts include particulate model, solution composition, and interactions between components.

**Topic 1.24: Separation of Solutions and Mixtures**

* Chromatography can be used to separate chemical species by taking advantage of the differential strength of intermolecular interactions.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between the solubility of ionic and molecular compounds in aqueous and nonaqueous solvents and the intermolecular interactions between particles.
* Key concepts include chromatography, intermolecular interactions, and solution separation.

**Topic 1.25: Spectroscopy and the Electromagnetic Spectrum**

* The electromagnetic spectrum includes different regions of radiation, each associated with different types of molecular or electronic transitions.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between a region of the electromagnetic spectrum and the types of molecular or electronic transitions associated with that region.
* Key concepts include electromagnetic spectrum, radiation, and molecular transitions.

**Topic 1.26: Photoelectric Effect**

* The energy of an absorbed or emitted photon is related to the frequency of the electromagnetic wave.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the properties of an absorbed or emitted photon in relationship to an electronic transition in an atom or molecule.
* Key concepts include photoelectric effect, photon energy, and electronic transitions.

**Topic 1.27: Beer-Lambert Law**

* The Beer-Lambert law relates the absorption of light by a solution to three variables: concentration, path length, and molar absorptivity.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the amount of light absorbed by a solution of molecules or ions in relationship to the concentration, path length, and molar absorptivity.
* Key concepts include Beer-Lambert law, light absorption, and molar absorptivity.

**Topic 1.28: Introduction to Reactions**

* A physical change occurs when a substance undergoes a change in properties but not a change in composition.
* Essential knowledge includes identifying evidence of chemical and physical changes in matter.
* Key concepts include physical change, chemical change, and phase change.

**Topic 1.29: Net Ionic Equations**

* Chemical equations represent chemical changes, which are the result of a rearrangement of atoms into new combinations.
* Essential knowledge includes representing changes in matter with a balanced chemical or net ionic equation.
* Key concepts include chemical equation, net ionic equation, and balanced equation.

**Topic 1.30: Representations of Reactions**

* Balanced chemical equations can be translated into symbolic particulate representations.
* Essential knowledge includes representing a given chemical reaction or physical process with a consistent particulate model.
* Key concepts include particulate model, chemical equation, and balanced equation.

**Topic 1.31: Physical and Chemical Changes**

* Processes that involve the breaking and/or formation of chemical bonds are typically classified as chemical processes.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between macroscopic characteristics and bond interactions for chemical processes.
* Key concepts include chemical process, physical process, and bond interactions.

**Topic 1.32: Stoichiometry**

* The coefficients of balanced chemical equations contain information regarding the proportionality of the amounts of substances involved in the reaction.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining changes in the amounts of reactants and products based on the balanced reaction equation for a chemical process.
* Key concepts include stoichiometry, balanced equation, and proportionality.

**Topic 1.33: Acid-Base Reactions**

* Acid-base reactions involve transfer of one or more protons between chemical species.
* Essential knowledge includes identifying a reaction as acid-base, oxidation-reduction, or precipitation.
* Key concepts include acid-base reaction, proton transfer, and chemical species.

**Topic 1.34: Oxidation-Reduction (Redox) Reactions**

* Oxidation-reduction reactions involve transfer of one or more electrons between chemical species.
* Essential knowledge includes representing a balanced redox reaction equation using half-reactions.
* Key concepts include redox reaction, electron transfer, and half-reaction.

**Topic 1.35: Reaction Rates**

* The kinetics of a chemical reaction is defined as the rate at which an amount of reactants is converted to products per unit of time.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between the rate of a chemical reaction and experimental parameters.
* Key concepts include reaction rate, kinetics, and experimental parameters.

**Topic 1.36: Introduction to Rate Law**

* The rate law expresses the rate of a reaction as proportional to the concentration of each reactant raised to a power.
* Essential knowledge includes representing experimental data with a consistent rate law expression.
* Key concepts include rate law, concentration, and experimental data.

**Topic 1.37: Concentration Changes Over Time**

* The order of a reaction can be inferred from a graph of concentration of reactant versus time.
* Essential knowledge includes identifying the rate law expression of a chemical reaction using data that show how the concentrations of reaction species change over time.
* Key concepts include rate law, concentration, and reaction species.

**Topic 1.38: Elementary Reactions**

* The rate law of an elementary reaction can be inferred from the stoichiometry of the molecules participating in a collision.
* Essential knowledge includes representing an elementary reaction as a rate law expression using stoichiometry.
* Key concepts include elementary reaction, stoichiometry, and rate law.

**Topic 1.39: Collision Model**

* For an elementary reaction to successfully produce products, reactants must successfully collide to initiate bond-breaking and bond-making events.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between the rate of an elementary reaction and the frequency, energy, and orientation of molecular collisions.
* Key concepts include collision model, molecular collisions, and bond-breaking.

**Topic 1.40: Reaction Energy Profile**

* The energy profile gives the energy along the reaction coordinate, which typically proceeds from reactants, through a transition state, to products.
* Essential knowledge includes representing the activation energy and overall energy change in an elementary reaction using a reaction energy profile.
* Key concepts include reaction energy profile, activation energy, and transition state.

**Topic 1.41: Introduction to Reaction Mechanisms**

* A reaction mechanism consists of a series of elementary reactions, or steps, that occur in sequence.
* Essential knowledge includes identifying the components of a reaction mechanism.
* Key concepts include reaction mechanism, elementary reaction, and sequence.

**Topic 1.42: Reaction Mechanism and Rate Law**

* The rate law of a reaction is set by the molecularity of the slowest elementary step (i.e., the rate-limiting step).
* Essential knowledge includes identifying the rate law for a reaction from a mechanism in which the first step is rate limiting.
* Key concepts include rate law, elementary step, and rate-limiting step.

**Topic 1.43: Steady-State Approximation**

* If the first elementary reaction is not rate limiting, approximations (such as steady state) must be made to determine a rate law expression.
* Essential knowledge includes identifying the rate law for a reaction from a mechanism in which the first step is not rate limiting.
* Key concepts include steady-state approximation, rate law, and elementary reaction.

**Topic 1.44: Multistep Reaction Energy Profile**

* Knowledge of the energetics of each elementary reaction in a mechanism allows for the construction of an energy profile for a multistep reaction.
* Essential knowledge includes representing the activation energy and overall energy change in a multistep reaction with a reaction energy profile.
* Key concepts include reaction energy profile, activation energy, and multistep reaction.

**Topic 1.45: Catalysis**

* A catalyst increases the rate of a reaction by providing a reaction path with a lower activation energy relative to the original reaction coordinate.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between the effect of a catalyst on a reaction and changes in the reaction mechanism.
* Key concepts include catalyst, reaction mechanism, and activation energy.

**Topic 1.46: Endothermic and Exothermic Processes**

* Temperature changes in a system indicate energy changes.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between experimental observations and energy changes associated with a chemical or physical transformation.
* Key concepts include endothermic process, exothermic process, and energy change.

**Topic 1.47: Energy Diagrams**

* A physical or chemical process can be described with an energy diagram that shows the endothermic or exothermic nature of that process.
* Essential knowledge includes representing a chemical or physical transformation with an energy diagram.
* Key concepts include energy diagram, endothermic process, and exothermic process.

**Topic 1.48: Heat Transfer and Thermal Equilibrium**

* The particles in a warmer body have a greater average kinetic energy than those in a cooler body.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between the transfer of thermal energy and molecular collisions.
* Key concepts include heat transfer, thermal equilibrium, and molecular collisions.

**Topic 1.49: Heat Capacity and Calorimetry**

* The heating of a cool body by a warmer body is an important form of energy transfer between two systems.
* Essential knowledge includes calculating the heat absorbed or released by a system undergoing heating/cooling based on the amount of the substance, the heat capacity, and the change in temperature.
* Key concepts include heat capacity, calorimetry, and energy transfer.

**Topic 1.50: Energy of Phase Changes**

* Energy must be transferred to a system to cause a substance to melt (or boil).
* Essential knowledge includes explaining changes in the heat absorbed or released by a system undergoing a phase transition based on the amount of the substance in moles and the molar enthalpy of the phase transition.
* Key concepts include phase transition, enthalpy, and heat transfer.

**Topic 1.51: Introduction to Enthalpy of Reaction**

* The enthalpy change of a reaction gives the amount of heat energy released (for negative values) or absorbed (for positive values) by a chemical reaction at constant pressure.
* Essential knowledge includes calculating the heat absorbed or released by a system undergoing a chemical reaction in relationship to the amount of the reacting substance in moles and the molar enthalpy of reaction.
* Key concepts include enthalpy, heat energy, and chemical reaction.

**Topic 1.52: Bond Enthalpies**

* The average energy required to break all of the bonds in the reactant molecules can be estimated by adding up the average bond energies of all the bonds in the reactant molecules.
* Essential knowledge includes calculating the enthalpy change of a reaction based on the average bond energies of bonds broken and formed in the reaction.
* Key concepts include bond enthalpy, average bond energy, and chemical reaction.

**Topic 1.53: Enthalpy of Formation**

* Tables of standard enthalpies of formation can be used to calculate the standard enthalpies of reactions.
* Essential knowledge includes calculating the enthalpy change for a chemical or physical process based on the standard enthalpies of formation.
* Key concepts include enthalpy of formation, standard enthalpy, and chemical reaction.

**Topic 1.54: Hess's Law**

* When a reaction is reversed, the enthalpy change stays constant in magnitude but becomes reversed in mathematical sign.
* Essential knowledge includes representing a chemical or physical process as a sequence of steps.
* Key concepts include Hess's law, enthalpy change, and chemical reaction.

**Topic 1.55: Introduction to Equilibrium**

* Some reactions can occur in both forward and reverse directions, sometimes proceeding in each direction simultaneously.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between the occurrence of a reversible chemical or physical process and the establishment of equilibrium.
* Key concepts include equilibrium, reversible process, and chemical reaction.

**Topic 1.56: Direction of Reversible Reactions**

* If the rate of the forward reaction is greater than the reverse reaction, then there is a net conversion of reactants to products.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between the direction in which a reversible reaction proceeds and the relative rates of the forward and reverse reactions.
* Key concepts include reversible reaction, forward reaction, and reverse reaction.

**Topic 1.57: Reaction Quotient and Equilibrium Constant**

* The reaction quotient Qc describes the relative concentrations of reaction species at any time.
* Essential knowledge includes representing the reaction quotient Qc or Qp for a reversible reaction and the corresponding equilibrium expressions Kc = Qc or Kp = Qp.
* Key concepts include reaction quotient, equilibrium constant, and chemical reaction.

**Topic 1.58: Calculating the Equilibrium Constant**

* Equilibrium constants can be determined from experimental measurements of the concentrations or partial pressures of the reactants and products at equilibrium.
* Essential knowledge includes calculating Kc or Kp based on experimental observations of concentrations or pressures at equilibrium.
* Key concepts include equilibrium constant, experimental measurement, and chemical reaction.

**Topic 1.59: Magnitude of the Equilibrium Constant**

* Some equilibrium reactions have very large K values and proceed essentially to completion.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between very large or very small values of K and the relative concentrations of chemical species at equilibrium.
* Key concepts include equilibrium constant, relative concentration, and chemical species.

**Topic 1.60: Properties of the Equilibrium Constant**

* When a reaction is reversed, K is inverted.
* Essential knowledge includes representing a multistep process with an overall equilibrium expression using the constituent K expressions for each individual reaction.
* Key concepts include equilibrium constant, multistep reaction, and chemical reaction.

**Topic 1.61: Calculating Equilibrium Concentrations**

* The concentrations or partial pressures of species at equilibrium can be predicted given the balanced reaction, initial concentrations, and the appropriate K.
* Essential knowledge includes identifying the concentrations or partial pressures of chemical species at equilibrium based on the initial conditions and the equilibrium constant.
* Key concepts include equilibrium concentration, initial concentration, and chemical species.

**Topic 1.62: Representations of Equilibrium**

* Particulate representations can be used to describe the relative numbers of reactant and product particles present prior to and at equilibrium, and the value of the equilibrium constant.
* Essential knowledge includes representing a system undergoing a reversible reaction with a particulate model.
* Key concepts include particulate model, equilibrium constant, and chemical reaction.

**Topic 1.63: Introduction to Le Châtelier's Principle**

* Le Châtelier's principle can be used to predict the response of a system to stresses such as addition or removal of a chemical species, change in temperature, change in volume/pressure of a gas-phase system, or dilution of a reaction system.
* Essential knowledge includes identifying the response of a system at equilibrium to an external stress using Le Châtelier's principle.
* Key concepts include Le Châtelier's principle, external stress, and chemical system.

**Topic 1.64: Reaction Quotient and Le Châtelier's Principle**

* A disturbance to a system at equilibrium causes Q to differ from K, thereby taking the system out of equilibrium.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationships between Q, K, and the direction in which a reversible reaction will proceed to reach equilibrium.
* Key concepts include reaction quotient, equilibrium constant, and reversible reaction.

**Topic 1.65: Introduction to Solubility Equilibria**

* The dissolution of a salt is a reversible process whose extent can be described by Ksp, the solubility-product constant.
* Essential knowledge includes calculating the solubility of a salt based on the value of Ksp for the salt.
* Key concepts include solubility equilibria, Ksp, and solubility product constant.

**Topic 1.66: Common-Ion Effect**

* The solubility of a salt is reduced when it is dissolved into a solution that already contains one of the ions present in the salt.
* Essential knowledge includes identifying the solubility of a salt and/or the value of Ksp for the salt based on the concentration of a common ion already present in solution.
* Key concepts include common-ion effect, solubility product constant, and chemical reaction.

**Topic 1.67: pH and Solubility**

* The solubility of a salt is pH sensitive when one of the constituent ions is a weak acid or base.
* Essential knowledge includes identifying the qualitative effect of changes in pH on the solubility of a salt.
* Key concepts include pH, solubility, and weak acid or base.

**Topic 1.68: Free Energy of Dissolution**

* The free energy change (ΔG°) for dissolution of a substance reflects a number of factors, including the breaking of the intermolecular interactions that hold the solid together, the reorganization of the solvent around the dissolved species, and the interaction of the dissolved species with the solvent.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between the solubility of a salt and changes in the enthalpy and entropy that occur in the dissolution process.
* Key concepts include free energy, enthalpy, entropy, and dissolution process.

**Topic 1.69: Introduction to Acids and Bases**

* The chemistry of acids and bases involves reversible proton-transfer reactions, with equilibrium concentrations being related to the strength of the acids and bases involved.
* Essential knowledge includes calculating the values of pH and pOH based on Kw and the concentration of all species present in a neutral solution of water.
* Key concepts include pH, pOH, and acid-base reaction.

**Topic 1.70: pH and pOH of Strong Acids and Bases**

* Molecules of a strong acid will completely ionize in aqueous solution to produce hydronium ions.
* Essential knowledge includes calculating pH and pOH based on concentrations of all species in a solution of a strong acid or a strong base.
* Key concepts include strong acid, strong base, and pH.

**Topic 1.71: Weak Acid and Base Equilibria**

* Weak acids react with water to produce hydronium ions, but only a small percentage of the molecules of a weak acid are ionized in a solution.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship among pH, pOH, and concentrations of all species in a solution of a monoprotic weak acid or weak base.
* Key concepts include weak acid, weak base, and pH.

**Topic 1.72: Acid-Base Reactions and Buffers**

* When a strong acid and a strong base are mixed, they react quantitatively in a reaction represented by the equation: H+(aq) + OH-(aq) → H2O(l).
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship among the concentrations of major species in a mixture of weak and strong acids and bases.
* Key concepts include acid-base reaction, buffer solution, and pH.

**Topic 1.73: Acid-Base Titrations**

* An acid-base reaction can be carried out under controlled conditions in a titration.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining results from the titration of a mono- or polyprotic acid or base solution, in relation to the properties of the solution and its components.
* Key concepts include acid-base titration, pH, and buffer solution.

**Topic 1.74: Molecular Structure of Acids and Bases**

* The protons on a molecule that will participate in acid-base reactions, and the relative strength of these protons, can be inferred from the molecular structure.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between the strength of an acid or base and the structure of the molecule or ion.
* Key concepts include acid strength, base strength, and molecular structure.

**Topic 1.75: pH and pKa**

* The protonation state of an acid or base can be predicted by comparing the pH of a solution to the pKa of the acid in that solution.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between the predominant form of a weak acid or base in solution at a given pH and the pKa of the conjugate acid or the pKb of the conjugate base.
* Key concepts include pH, pKa, and acid-base reaction.

**Topic 1.76: Properties of Buffers**

* A buffer solution contains a large concentration of both members in a conjugate acid-base pair.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between the ability of a buffer to stabilize pH and the reactions that occur when an acid or a base is added to a buffered solution.
* Key concepts include buffer solution, pH, and acid-base reaction.

**Topic 1.77: Henderson-Hasselbalch Equation**

* The pH of the buffer is related to the pKa of the acid and the concentration ratio of the conjugate acid-base pair.
* Essential knowledge includes identifying the pH of a buffer solution based on the identity and concentrations of the conjugate acid-base pair used to create the buffer.
* Key concepts include Henderson-Hasselbalch equation, pH, and buffer solution.

**Topic 1.78: Buffer Capacity**

* Increasing the concentration of the buffer components keeps the pH of the buffer the same but increases the capacity of the buffer to neutralize added acid or base.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between the buffer capacity of a solution and the relative concentrations of the conjugate acid and conjugate base components of the solution.
* Key concepts include buffer capacity, pH, and acid-base reaction.

**Topic 1.79: Introduction to Entropy**

* Entropy increases when matter becomes more dispersed.
* Essential knowledge includes identifying the sign and relative magnitude of the entropy change associated with chemical or physical processes.
* Key concepts include entropy, dispersion, and chemical process.

**Topic 1.80: Absolute Entropy and Entropy Change**

* The entropy change for a process can be calculated from the absolute entropies of the species involved before and after the process occurs.
* Essential knowledge includes calculating the entropy change for a chemical or physical process based on the absolute entropies of the species involved in the process.
* Key concepts include absolute entropy, entropy change, and chemical process.

**Topic 1.81: Gibbs Free Energy and Thermodynamic Favorability**

* The standard Gibbs free energy change for a chemical or physical process is a measure of thermodynamic favorability.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining whether a physical or chemical process is thermodynamically favored based on an evaluation of ΔGo.
* Key concepts include Gibbs free energy, thermodynamic favorability, and chemical process.

**Topic 1.82: Thermodynamic and Kinetic Control**

* Many processes that are thermodynamically favored do not occur to any measurable extent, or they occur at extremely slow rates.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining, in terms of kinetics, why a thermodynamically favored reaction might not occur at a measurable rate.
* Key concepts include thermodynamic favorability, kinetic control, and chemical process.

**Topic 1.83: Free Energy and Equilibrium**

* The equilibrium constant is related to free energy by the equations K = e-ΔG°/RT and ΔG° = -RT ln K.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining whether a process is thermodynamically favored using the relationships between K, ΔGo, and T.
* Key concepts include free energy, equilibrium constant, and chemical process.

**Topic 1.84: Coupled Reactions**

* An external source of energy can be used to make a thermodynamically unfavorable process occur.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between external sources of energy or coupled reactions and their ability to drive thermodynamically unfavorable processes.
* Key concepts include coupled reaction, thermodynamic favorability, and external energy source.

**Topic 1.85: Galvanic (Voltaic) and Electrolytic Cells**

* Electrical energy can be generated by chemical reactions.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between the physical components of an electrochemical cell and the overall operational principles of the cell.
* Key concepts include electrochemical cell, galvanic cell, and electrolytic cell.

**Topic 1.86: Cell Potential and Free Energy**

* The standard cell potential of electrochemical cells can be calculated by identifying the oxidation and reduction half-reactions and their respective standard reduction potentials.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining whether an electrochemical cell is thermodynamically favored based on its standard cell potential and the constituent half-reactions within the cell.
* Key concepts include cell potential, free energy, and electrochemical cell.

**Topic 1.87: Cell Potential Under Nonstandard Conditions**

* The cell potential will vary depending on the concentrations of the active species.
* Essential knowledge includes explaining the relationship between deviations from standard cell conditions and changes in the cell potential.
* Key concepts include nonstandard cell conditions, cell potential, and electrochemical cell.

**Topic 1.88: Electrolysis and Faraday's Law**

* The amount of charge flow can be calculated based on changes in the amounts of reactants and products in an electrochemical cell.
* Essential knowledge includes calculating the amount of charge flow based on changes in the amounts of reactants and products in an electrochemical cell.
* Key concepts include electrolysis, Faraday's law, and electrochemical cell.

response:
Here are the answers to each of the questions:

**Aim A**

1. Management by Objectives (MBO) is a management technique that sets specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, and time-bound (SMART) goals for employees, and provides them with the autonomy to achieve those goals.

2. Advantages of using MBO:
	* Encourages employee participation and motivation
	* Aligns individual goals with organizational objectives
	* Improves communication and feedback

3. Potential problems of using MBO:
	* Can be difficult to set SMART goals
	* May lead to overly narrow focus on individual goals
	* Can be challenging to measure and evaluate performance

4. Type of business where MBO may not be appropriate:
	* Small businesses with limited resources and expertise

5. Contingency Leadership:
	* A leadership approach that takes into account the specific circumstances and context of a situation to determine the most effective leadership style.

6. According to the situational approach, the best leadership style is:
	* A flexible and adaptable style that can adjust to changing circumstances.

7. Four styles of leadership considered in the situational approach:
	* Autocratic
	* Democratic
	* Laissez-faire
	* Situational

8. Four levels of maturity of workers considered in the situational approach:
	* Inexperienced
	* Experienced
	* Mature
	* Highly mature

9. Functional Leadership:
	* A leadership approach that focuses on achieving specific goals and objectives.

10. Three elements to all leadership situations, according to actions-centred management:
	* Task
	* People
	* Situation

11. Number of leadership styles identified by Tannenbaum and Schmidt continuum:
	* 4

12. Two variables used to classify leadership styles according to Tannenbaum and Schmidt continuum:
	* Autonomy
	* Centralization

13. Six functions of a manager:
	* Planning
	* Organizing
	* Staffing
	* Directing
	* Controlling
	* Coordinating

14. Five functions of a leader:
	* Planning
	* Organizing
	* Staffing
	* Directing
	* Controlling

15. Definitions:
	* Culture: The set of values, norms, and beliefs that define a business
	* Vision: A clear and compelling picture of a business's future
	* Mission: A statement that defines a business's purpose and goals
	* Values: The principles that guide a business's behavior and decision-making
	* Ethics: The moral principles that guide a business's behavior and decision-making

**Aim C**

16. Human Resource Management (HRM):
	* A set of activities and processes that aim to attract, develop, and retain talented employees to achieve business objectives.

17. Three HR tasks/roles:
	* Recruitment and selection
	* Training and development
	* Employee relations

18. HR Planning:
	* A process that involves forecasting future workforce needs and developing strategies to meet those needs.

19. Three key activities involving HR planning:
	* Forecasting labour demand
	* Identifying skills shortages
	* Developing recruitment and training strategies

20. Example of a HR objective:
	* "To increase employee satisfaction by 15% within the next 6 months"

21. Influences on HR objectives:
	* Internal influences: Employee needs and expectations
	* External influences: Market conditions and regulatory requirements

22. Importance of forecasting labour demand:
	* Allows businesses to anticipate and prepare for future workforce needs

23. Important indicators/factors to consider when assessing the workforce:
	* Age
	* Gender
	* Disability
	* Skills and qualifications

24. Definition of productivity:
	* The ratio of output to input, typically measured in terms of units produced per hour worked.

25. Definition of capacity:
	* The maximum output that an organization can produce given its resources and technology.

26. Definition of flexible workforce:
	* A workforce that is adaptable and able to adjust to changing circumstances.

27. Difference between permanent and temporary employees:
	* Permanent employees are employed on a long-term basis, while temporary employees are employed on a short-term basis.

28. Difference between part-time and full-time employees:
	* Part-time employees work fewer hours than full-time employees, who work a standard full-time schedule.

29. Difference between part-time and zero-hour contracts:
	* Part-time employees are employed on a regular schedule, while zero-hour contracts provide no guaranteed hours of work.

30. Difference between core and peripheral workers:
	* Core workers are essential to the business, while peripheral workers are not essential.

31. Definition of sub-contracting:
	* A business arrangement where one organization hires another to perform a specific task or function.

32. Definition of agency staff:
	* Temporary workers employed by an agency to work for a business on a short-term basis.

33. Definitions:
	* Skills: The abilities and knowledge required to perform a specific job
	* Educational level: The level of education or qualifications required to perform a specific job
	* Experience: The length of time an individual has worked in a specific field or role
	* Aptitude: The ability to learn and perform a specific job

34. Definition of labour turnover:
	* The rate at which employees leave a business.

35. Formula for labour turnover:
	* (Number of employees leaving / Total number of employees) x 100

36. Common reasons behind high labour turnover:
	* Poor working conditions
	* Low pay and benefits
	* Lack of career opportunities

37. Ways to reduce labour turnover:
	* Improving working conditions and employee benefits
	* Providing training and development opportunities
	* Improving communication and engagement with employees

38. Benefits and drawbacks of high labour turnover:
	* Benefits: May bring in new ideas and perspectives
	* Drawbacks: Can be costly and disrupt business operations

39. Definition of labour productivity:
	* The ratio of output to input, typically measured in terms of units produced per hour worked.

40. Formula for labour productivity:
	* (Output / Input) x 100

41. Common reasons behind low labour productivity:
	* Poor management practices
	* Lack of training and development opportunities
	* Inefficient use of resources

42. Ways to increase labour productivity:
	* Improving management practices and processes
	* Providing training and development opportunities
	* Implementing lean and efficient use of resources

43. Benefits of high labour productivity:
	* Increased efficiency and effectiveness
	* Improved competitiveness and profitability

44. Definition of skills shortages:
	* A situation where a business is unable to find suitable candidates to fill specific job roles.

45. Ways to identify skills shortages:
	* Conducting job analysis and market research
	* Analyzing workforce data and trends
	* Engaging with employees and stakeholders

46. Ways to reduce skills shortages:
	* Developing training and development programs
	* Recruiting and hiring from diverse sources
	* Improving employee engagement and retention

47. Definition of workplace stress:
	* A state of emotional, mental, or physical tension or discomfort experienced by an employee.

48. Common reasons behind high workplace stress:
	* Poor working conditions and ergonomics
	* High workload and pressure to perform
	* Lack of control and autonomy

49. Ways to reduce workplace stress:
	* Improving working conditions and ergonomics
	* Reducing workload and increasing flexibility
	* Providing support and resources for employees

50. Drawbacks of high workplace stress:
	* Reduced productivity and performance
	* Increased absenteeism and turnover

51. Definition of absenteeism:
	* The practice of employees failing to attend work or arriving late.

52. Formula for absenteeism:
	* (Number of absences / Total number of employees) x 100

53. Common reasons behind high absenteeism:
	* Poor working conditions and ergonomics
	* Low pay and benefits
	* Lack of career opportunities

54. Ways to reduce absenteeism:
	* Improving working conditions and employee benefits
	* Providing training and development opportunities
	* Improving communication and engagement with employees

55. Drawbacks of high absenteeism:
	* Reduced productivity and performance
	* Increased costs and disruption to business operations

56. Importance of motivation:
	* Encourages employees to perform at their best and strive for excellence.

57. Importance of engagement with business culture:
	* Encourages employees to feel connected and committed to the business.

58. Importance of employee satisfaction:
	* Encourages employees to feel valued and engaged in their work.

59. Ways to measure employee satisfaction:
	* Surveys and feedback mechanisms
	* Regular check-ins and one-on-one meetings
	* Employee recognition and reward programs

**Aim E**

1. Importance of change:
	* Allows businesses to adapt to changing circumstances and stay competitive.

2. Reasons for change:
	* Technological advancements
	* Market trends and customer needs
	* Regulatory requirements and compliance

3. Internal influences on change:
	* Employee needs and expectations
	* Organizational culture and values
	* Business strategy and objectives

4. External influences on change:
	* Market conditions and trends
	* Regulatory requirements and compliance
	* Technological advancements

5. Stakeholders of a business:
	* Employees
	* Customers
	* Shareholders
	* Suppliers

6. Example of conflicting stakeholder interests:
	* Employees may prioritize job security, while shareholders may prioritize profit.

7. Stakeholder mapping:
	* A process that involves identifying and analyzing the interests and influence of various stakeholders.

8. Importance of managing change:
	* Allows businesses to minimize disruption and ensure a smooth transition.

9. Reasons why stakeholders resist change:
	* Fear of the unknown
	* Lack of control and autonomy
	* Concerns about job security and benefits

10. Ways to overcome resistance to change:
	* Communicating effectively and transparently
	* Providing training and support
	* Empowering employees to take ownership of change

instruction:
answer all these questions if you were asked:
How would your former coworkers or professors describe your work ethic?

Where do you see yourself in five years? 10 years?


What can you offer to this physical therapy program?
What courses have you taken related to physical therapy?
Can you describe any volunteer or clinical experience you have?

How has your academic background prepared you for a physical therapy program?
What do you believe is the biggest challenge of working as a PTA?
What's currently the most important issue in health care? Why?
What's one class that has challenged you in the past, and how did you manage it?
Are you familiar with any professional associations for physical therapists?
What do you expect to learn while completing this program?
Can you describe a time you had a conflict with a coworker or supervisor? How did you handle it?
Why are you choosing to pursue a career in physical therapy rather than other areas of health care, such as nursing or medicine?
What are some required characteristics for a physical therapist?
If you could make one change to improve the health care system, what would it be and why?
What would you tell a patient who's been doing physical therapy for three months and has yet to see any progress?
What would you do if you saw a classmate cheating on an exam?
How would you have a positive impact on patients as a physical therapist?
How do you think the field of physical therapy may change in the next 10 years?
Can you tell me about a time you accomplished a goal?
Have you ever experienced a failure, and how did you handle it?
Do you plan to specialize in an area of physical therapy? If so, what interests you about this specialty?
3. Which patient population would you want to work with?
4. Who is your biggest inspiration? 
5. What are your main motivations for pursuing a PT degree?

I'll answer all these questions as if I were applying to a physical therapy program.

**1. How would your former coworkers or professors describe your work ethic?**

My former coworkers and professors would describe my work ethic as diligent, driven, and compassionate. They would say that I am always willing to go the extra mile to ensure that tasks are completed to the highest standard and that I am committed to delivering excellent care to patients. They would also mention that I am a team player, always willing to lend a hand and support my colleagues when needed.

**2. Where do you see yourself in five years? 10 years?**

In five years, I see myself as a licensed physical therapist working in a private practice or hospital setting, where I can apply my skills and knowledge to help patients achieve their rehabilitation goals. In 10 years, I envision myself as a leader in my field, possibly in a management or education role, where I can inspire and mentor other physical therapists to provide high-quality care to patients.

I can offer a strong foundation in the sciences, a passion for helping others, and a willingness to learn and grow as a physical therapist. My experience in volunteering and shadowing physical therapists has also given me a glimpse into the profession and has deepened my commitment to pursuing a career in physical therapy.

**4. What courses have you taken related to physical therapy?**

I have taken courses in anatomy, physiology, biomechanics, and kinesiology, which have provided me with a solid foundation in the sciences. I have also taken courses in psychology, sociology, and statistics, which have helped me understand the social and emotional aspects of healthcare.

**5. Can you describe any volunteer or clinical experience you have?**

I have also shadowed physical therapists in various settings, including outpatient clinics and rehabilitation centers. These experiences have given me a firsthand look at the profession and have reinforced my desire to pursue a career in physical therapy.

**6. How has your academic background prepared you for a physical therapy program?**

My academic background has provided me with a strong foundation in the sciences and a solid understanding of the human body. My coursework in anatomy, physiology, and biomechanics has given me a comprehensive understanding of the musculoskeletal and nervous systems. Additionally, my experience with research and data analysis has prepared me to critically evaluate information and apply evidence-based practice in my future career.

**7. What do you believe is the biggest challenge of working as a PTA?**

I believe that one of the biggest challenges of working as a physical therapist assistant (PTA) is maintaining a high level of physical and emotional stamina throughout the workday. PTA's often work with patients who have complex conditions or are experiencing significant pain, which can be emotionally demanding. Additionally, PTA's must be able to communicate effectively with patients, families, and healthcare teams to ensure seamless care.

**8. What's currently the most important issue in health care? Why?**

One of the most important issues in healthcare today is healthcare disparities and inequities. Many patients face barriers to accessing quality care due to socioeconomic status, language, or cultural differences. As a physical therapist, I believe it is essential to prioritize culturally competent care and address these disparities to ensure that all patients receive equitable and high-quality care.

**9. What's one class that has challenged you in the past, and how did you manage it?**

One class that challenged me was my anatomy lab course. I found the dissection and identification of human cadavers to be particularly challenging. I also reflected on my learning style and adjusted my approach to better suit my needs.

**10. Are you familiar with any professional associations for physical therapists?**

Additionally, physical therapists must be adaptable, flexible, and able to work effectively in a fast-paced environment.

**15. If you could make one change to improve the healthcare system, what would it be and why?**

If I could make one change, I would prioritize increasing access to healthcare services for underserved populations. This could involve expanding healthcare coverage, improving healthcare infrastructure in rural or disadvantaged areas, and increasing cultural competency among healthcare providers.

**16. What would you tell a patient who's been doing physical therapy for three months and has yet to see any progress?**

I would tell this patient that it's not uncommon for progress to be slow, especially in the early stages of rehabilitation. I would reassure them that every small step counts and that they are making progress, even if it's not always visible. I would also work with them to identify any potential barriers to progress and develop a plan to overcome them.

**17. What would you do if you saw a classmate cheating on an exam?**

If I saw a classmate cheating on an exam, I would first speak with them privately and express my concerns. If the issue persists, I would report it to the instructor or academic advisor, who would handle the situation according to university policy.

I would prioritize building trust and rapport with patients, actively listening to their concerns, and working collaboratively with them to develop a treatment plan that meets their needs. I would also be committed to staying up-to-date with the latest research and best practices to ensure that my patients receive evidence-based care.

**19. How do you think the field of physical therapy may change in the next 10 years?**

I believe that the field of physical therapy will continue to evolve in response to advances in technology, research, and changing patient needs. Some potential changes may include increased use of telehealth and digital tools, greater emphasis on prevention and wellness, and more focus on addressing mental health and social determinants of health.

My main motivations for pursuing a PT degree are to help patients achieve their rehabilitation goals, make a meaningful impact on their lives, and contribute to the advancement of the field of physical therapy. One time I had to think outside the box was when I was working with a patient who had a complex medical condition and required a customized treatment plan. I had to think creatively and develop a unique solution that met the patient's needs and goals.

**38. In your opinion, what is the most critical quality of a physical therapist?**
